awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: An Ethnographic Study of Lay Participation in the United States Criminal Justice System
awd_abstract_narration:
This project undertakes an anthropological study of the United States federal jury system, focusing on how prosecutors pick jurors. The process by which citizens are selected or excused from jury service has not been studied ethnographically, leaving lawyers and social scientists with an incomplete understanding of the relationship between attorneys' practices of social evaluation and their formulations of justice as dimensions of their professionalism. Significant contributions to sociolegal research and the legal profession flow from this project. It will shed light on how prosecutors evaluate individuals who report for jury service in relation to the case at hand. A key finding in this research to date is that prosecutors draw on multiple interpretive resources as they seek to compose a jury based on the attributes of jurors. These resources include their professional training in the law, their collegial consultation as they prepare cases for trial, and their personal experience, among other sources of social knowledge. Since jurors are by definition strangers to prosecutors, prosecutors often use iconic "types" as shorthand for the ways social characteristics align (in their own understandings) with different analytical abilities and/or orientations to crime and punishment. This research will also illuminate how prosecutors translate their felt obligation to do justice into action, as they work with juries. The insights of this study contribute to the anthropology of law and sociolegal studies, and can be returned as well to the legal profession through Continuing Legal Education (CLE) courses that focus on the theory and practice of jury selection.

Drawing on ethnographic methods, this research will include participant observation in multiple U.S. Attorney's Offices and courtrooms in a federal judicial district. The researcher will conduct semi-structured and unstructured interviews that explore how prosecutors' ideas about lay decision-makers shift from one juror(and trial)to the next. It will also involve the analysis of trial transcripts.

por.por_cntn:
My NSF-funded doctoral research utilized empirical methods to understand the role that juries play in the organization of prosecutions in the United States. My point of departure was the decline of the American jury trial. Criminal jury trials are currently the rare exception rather than the rule— particularly in federal courts. In 2017, for example, just 2.15 percent of federal criminal defendants were tried by juries, down from about 60 percent in the mid-nineteenth-century. Although practitioners and legal scholars have bemoaned this fact and its implications for individual defendants, there remains dispute about the influence of the right to a jury trial on the operation of our justice system.

The impact of the right to a jury trial on legal practice is an empirical question that cannot be answered by caseload statistics or quantitative research alone, because it has implications for our entire legal culture. In addition to its practical fact-finding role, the jury has long been inflected with distinct values, commitments, and perceived incentives for litigants. Drawing on my training as a legal anthropologist, I sought to determine how the scarcity of jury trials affects federal prosecutors’ work. Ethnographic legal research, which aims to develop empirically-grounded accounts of attorneys’ work, was an essential component of this project. After obtaining research approval, I interviewed 133 Assistant U.S. Attorneys and participated in dozens of case preparation meetings and trial proceedings. What I found surprised me. Prosecutors have so internalized the unpredictable interventions of jurors that even the remote possibility of a trial alters their behavior in significant ways. For example, it affects their assessments of ongoing investigations, critiques of case theories, as well as their written decisions to pursue or decline cases.

Stemming from this research, my article Prosecuting in the Shadow of the Jury, 113 NW. U. L. REV. (forthcoming 2019), sheds light on the jury’s role in the U.S. legal system. I find that the relatively minute number (2%) of criminal cases tried by juries has an outsized impact on lawyers’ decision-making. The article empirically demonstrates the role of imagined jurors, for example, in decisions to indict defendants and considerations that influence plea negotiations. While this article focuses on how prosecutors impute justice concerns to hypothetical jurors, another law review article examined prosecutors’ assimilation of information about those actually impaneled in trials. This piece, titled Peer-Review: Navigating Uncertainty in the United States Jury System, 6 U.C. IRVINE L. REV. 169 (2016), argued that prosecutors’ approaches to voir dire are informed by colleagues’ experiences trying similar cases— among other variables. Focusing on case narratives prosecutors construct as part of opening and closing statements, a peer-reviewed article, titled With Jurors in Mind: An Ethnographic Study of Prosecutors’ Narratives, reveals that prosecutors eagerly constitute hypothetical and abstracted identities for themselves. In the process, they eschew traits like overzealousness and imprecision, for example, in favor of characteristics that emphasize their equanimity and attention to detail. This second piece was published in 2017 in the Law, Culture, and the Humanities Journal.

At a time when lay participation is being questioned in other domains, including electoral politics, my defense of the jury system is timely and significant. Ethnographic approaches will offer powerful insights, as debates about legal reform demand an empirically grounded understanding of crucial decision-making processes that too often unfold behind closed doors. To this end, my scholarship will continue to offer novel evidence that jurors provide a key form of accountability and serve as a generative ethical and strategic resource for professionals who may encounter them.
